Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Program in the Biochemical Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration: This award, made to the University of Kentucky, is supported by the Department of Defense ASSURE program and the NSF Division of Biological Infrastructure in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO) and the Division of Chemistry (CHE) and in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS). The University of Kentucky will provide research training for 10 weeks for 8 students, during the summers of 2010-2013. Students will complete an intensive ten week program in the biochemical sciences, participating in cutting-edge research in structural biology, biophysics, molecular biology and genetics, and cell biology. All participants will be assigned a faculty mentor and are expected to conduct their research in an ethical and responsible manner. The Program includes seminar series on careers in the biochemical sciences and the research process, including presentation and publication of data, and research ethics. Participants will also have the opportunity to participate in a number of organized social events. The Program will culminate in a widely-attended symposium featuring oral research presentations by participants. Recruitment is focused on the students from the Appalachian area and under-represented groups. Successful applicants will receive a stipend, housing in student dormitories, and reimbursement for travel to and from Lexington, Kentucky. Success will be tracked through surveys of participants both during and in the years after attending the Program. Assessment will involve use of a common tool developed by the NSF BIO REU and tools developed by the Program. Additional information and application materials can be found at http://www.mc.uky.edu/Biochemistry/REU/, or by contacting the Program Director, Dr. Trevor Creamer, at Trevor.Creamer@uky.edu or 859-323-6037.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this NSF REU Summer Program in the Biochemical Sciences (DBI-1004931) were to provide cutting-edge research experiences and exposure to potential careers in science to undergraduate students recruited largely from Appalachia and under-represented groups. Each year eight students spent ten weeks in the Department of Molecular and Cellular Biochemistry at the University of Kentucky. There they worked on research projects with faculty mentors and received exposure to the broad range of career options available to people with degrees in biochemistry or related fields. We were very successful with recruiting from our target groups, with almost 50% of our participants coming from Appalachia and a further 25% from under-represented groups. The remaining 25% of participants were drawn from small colleges and universities with few opportunities for participating in research. We were similarly successful with exposing the participants to career opportunities in that we saw a substantial increase in their how informed they felt leaving the program versus when they first arrived on campus. Notably we observed a small, but significant increase in their desire to pursue a career in research. In sum, we have been able to provide experiences to these students that have not only educated and excited them about doing scientific research, but also informed them as to what careers they may choose to pursue upon graduation from their home institutions.
